newsitem.title: UK: Violent crime rises in England and Wales.
newsitem.headline: Violent crime rises in England and Wales.

text.p: Crime rose in England and Wales for the first time in two years, the government reported on Tuesday, with the biggest increase in violent crimes like assault and rape.
The Home Office (interior ministry) reported overall recorded crimes had risen 0.4 percent in the year to June.
"This compares to the 12 months to June 1995 which saw a fall of five per cent and the 12 months to June 1994 in which recorded crime fell by 5.5 per cent," it said in a statement.

The rise was certain to embarrass the Conservative government of Prime Minister John Major, ahead of his party's annual conference next month. Crime has been a big issue in British politics and is likely to figure highly as a general election, due by next May, approaches.
The number of violent crimes had risen 10 percent, with assaults, rapes and muggings all on the increase.
But police said violent crimes are still rare in Britain, making up only six percent of all crimes.
